core.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: the hard central part of a fruit such as an apple
core.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Remove the cores, and bake the apples for 40 minutes.
core.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: the most important or central part of something
core.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: The core of the book focuses on the period between 1660 and 1857.
Debt is at the core of the problem.
core.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a number of people who form a group which is very important to an organization
core.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: The business needs a new core of trained administrators.
core.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: the central part of the Earth or any other planet
core.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: the central part of a nuclear reactor
core.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: to remove the centre from a fruit
core.translation[3].definitions[0].defin: a part of something that is important in relation to its growth, future etc
core.translation[3].definitions[0].examp: The business park has created a core of new technology businesses in a city long affected by economic decline.
A core of major states support the national organizationâ€™s plan.
core.translation[4].definitions[0].defin: the business, activity etc that makes the most money for a company and that is considered to be its most important and central one
core.translation[4].definitions[0].examp: US car maker Chrysler is to sell off its $1 billion technology arm to concentrate resources on its core business.
